Situation1: They provide in-depth guidance on a critical task where mistakes could have serious consequences.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: An office function with colleagues of all genders is scheduled this afternoon.
Story:
As a mentor, I take pride in guiding my team, especially when the stakes are high. Today, I’m expected to lead a critical training session, one where every detail matters and any misstep could have serious consequences for the project. My mentees look to me for confidence and clarity, and I know I must be fully present, approachable, and set an example.

But this afternoon, the company is hosting an office function—a rare chance for the whole team to bond, including colleagues from other departments and all genders. The invitation specifically mentions a “business casual” dress code, and I know from past events that most people interpret this as short sleeves and relaxed attire. As a Muslim, I am committed to dressing modestly, covering my arms and legs as part of my faith. I worry that my choice of clothing will make me stand out, perhaps even seem distant or unapproachable to those I’m supposed to mentor.

I feel the weight of both roles pressing on me. I want to be the mentor my team needs, blending in and making everyone comfortable, but I also want to honor my beliefs. The expectations seem to pull me in opposite directions, and as the clock ticks closer to the event, I find myself torn, unsure which part of myself to prioritize.
